Description: Modern Historians, and their scientific guess seem to conclude that both Egyptian and Canaanite armies were numbered at around 10,000 for both sides with Egyptian at the advantage. The Egyptian fielded their armies with both professional and mercenary troops from all over Levant and Nubia, while the Canaanites gathered their armies from their militias and nearby allied tribes.

Similar to many other ancient battles, the record of the Battle of Megiddo was written by the victor that is the Ancient Egyptian. This record can be found in the Temple of Amun-Re’s hieroglyph wall, which mostly conveys the righteousness of Thutmose's invasion to subdue his wretch enemy (the king of Kadesh). The record did not detail the event of the battle nor the army composition of either side. So The number given here is an exaggeration to narrate the epicness of the first recorded battle in the history of humankind.

Anthony J. Spalinger provides a more conservative estimation of the size of both armies in his book based on the Egyptian record of war spoils obtained from the plunder of the Canaanite war camp at roughly a thousand horses and two thousand chariots. Then the size of Aruna Pass which the Egyptian army traversed to reach Meggido can only support a small marching rank. Hence, the ten thousand numbers on both sides are unlikely.
